children.text: Hello and welcome to the UFO Connection. I'm your host, Cynthia Siegel. Our show today is about a very important event: September 19, 1961. Betty and Barney Hill bringing on the beginning of the first official abduction reports. And we have an extraordinary honor tonight on our show because we have on, as our guest, Betty Hill speaking with us all the way from New Hampshire about this landmark case and remarkable UFO sightings that have been going on for decades in the New Hampshire hills outside her home ever since this event has taken place. So please join me in this remarkable opportunity and honor to hear one of the most important people in UFO history: Betty Hill. Betty, thank you so much for joining us. Can you hear me okay?
Yes, I can. Hello.
Hello, we are so honored to have you on our show! It's just amazing. We appreciate your giving us this time.
Thank you.
Siegel and Hill discuss the unwanted publicity they received after their story went public in 1965, which began the process of categorizing the Hills as abductees in the popular consciousness.
Now, you've had a lot of media attention---which in the beginning was not very welcome to you, was it?---because of this abduction experience.
Actually, right after this happened we were able to keep it quiet---
Yes, for how---
For four years.
Four years. Boy, that's not easy. Now what happened---now I understand you didn't willingly suddenly go public with this---
No.
What was the event?
How it became known was an investigative reporter for a Boston newspaper somehow heard about our experience and it was published on the front pages of this Boston newspaper for five days.
Wow. Five days---
Without ever meeting us. We had to go to the go to the store to buy the newspaper to see what was being said.
Well in fact, didn't this reporter approach you asking to interview you and you refused?
Right, he had he had contacted us---
So he---
---we said we were not interested in publicity.

Yeah, but he went behind your back anyway and without your input published these articles over a five-day period. What kind of an impression did or tone were the articles? How did he make you look to the public?
Actually, they were very accurate.
Hmmmmm.
Whoever his source was it was good.
Okay... so he was accurate about the event, but how did people react? Like what happened when this article---these articles suddenly appeared?
Well... uh...
Here, we see the unexpected rise of both celebrity status and social ostracization in the life of the abductee.
This was in the early 60s, were you worried about your reputation at that point?
Not really. Actually, we didn't know even though the articles were going to be published---
Mmmm.
---and we came home and the whole house is surrounded by reporters.
Oh! Oh, what a---that sounds awful.
And we all said, what's happening? And they said, you are!
[loud laughter] You're what's happening!
So they brought the article, the newspaper, in and I grabbed it ran in the bathroom and locked the door and read it.
[laughter] Just to keep them away from you, huh?
I wanted to see---I mean, first of all, I wanted to see what was being said.
Yes.
I wanted to see how accurate he was.
Yes.
And [feedback] I was amazed, he was accurate.
Uh-huh.
Yep.
Siegel acknowledges that Hill's storytelling process is likely rehearsed, equating Hill herself with the story she is about to tell.

Okay, now let's---let's tell people what the actual event was. I know you're very seasoned at telling this story. As I said it truly is---first of all it's one of the most impeccable cases, there's a remarkable amount of physical evidence and nobody has been able to dispute it. But it has many phases and components to it so we're going to spend the whole first half of the show on that night and that event and what followed and the evidence that you came across afterwards. So if you could start us out, tell us where you are, what was happening.

Barney Hill has been dead for over three decades at the time of the interview. His presence in the interview is a ghostly one, but his own resistance to the category of "abductee" appears through Betty's descriptions.

Okay, September 19, 1961. Barney and I are in Montreal, Canada and we were planning to stay there overnight. But then in late afternoon we heard a weather report that there was a hurricane coming up the coast and it might hit Portsmouth.
Which is your hometown.
Right, so we decided maybe we should head for home.
Okay.

So in late afternoon, we left Montreal---and it was a leisurely drive home, we were in no hurry. And we just decided that if we became too tired on the way home we'd pull off and have a little nap. But so we were in Colebrook, New Hampshire, which is just over the line from Canada.
Okay, on the way home to Portsmouth.
On the way home. And we stopped and had a snack to eat so that we always knew what time it was when we left. It was five minutes past ten.
Okay.

And then we started down through the White Mountains of New Hampshire and no traffic, beautiful night moon is full, bright, we're driving along, relaxed---because we've been driving, we've been in Canada for a few days before we went to Montreal.
Yeah.
And we're enjoying ourselves. And all of a sudden I saw what I thought was a new star in the sky.
And you're a seasoned experienced stargazer because of your beautiful open skies and clear skies in New Hampshire.

Right. [coughing] I was quite well acquainted with the skies generally, but this star was coming in next to the moon and it was getting bigger and bigger and bigger and brighter. So we were curious and Barney stopped the car and we got out to look at this star. And as we're looking at it, it changed direction and flew in front of the face of the moon. So we knew it wasn't a star at that point.
Could you make out the shape, or did it just appear round like a standard star---
Actually we couldn't see a shape too much, but what we saw were multi-colored beams of light shooting out from the craft.
Wow.
So it was really quite spectacular right in the beginning.
My, even at that distance you could see lights, multi-colored lights.
Yeah.
Wow.
And then, while we're standing out there---well first of all, we had our dog with us.
Yes, your---

So I let the dog out of the car and I put the dog back in the car, and at this point this obect changed direction and began coming in towards us. Now, this was puzzling because first of all, 1961, I don't think either Barney and I had ever really---we'd heard something about flying saucers, but we didn't know anything about them.
Okay.
And so we were curious about this craft.
Okay, so there wasn't any fear at that point, you just kept pulling off---
Oh no, just curiosity.
Okay.
And then actually it followed us for about 30 miles.
That's pretty long.
We would slow down and it would, and it paced us.
Ahh---how far away was it at this point, Betty?
Oh, not very far.
Not very far? What does that mean?
We're coming down through the mountains, and the highway would curve and the UFO would go straight over the mountain, come out there to the end of the mountain, and sit there and wait for us.
Oh, so it would pause and hover in midair and then start to move again as you---
When we sort of came up to it, it would start flying beside us.
Now wait, I still need to get an idea of how close we're talking. Are we talking, um, airplane?
Oh, no no no.
Airplane height or star height or cloud height or---
We're talking about, well let's see, the mountain's probably at four or five thousand feet.
Okay.
Okay. And I would say the craft was 50, maybe 50 feet above the, above the peaks.
Okay.
And the mountains, actually the roads, the highways are right there next to the mountains and so on.
Yes, yes.
You know, there's no space in between.
Right, right.
This is the first instance of Hill using humor and describing a light-hearted, curious interaction with her alien captors.

So it was close. And so we got to an area known as Indian Head. Just before we got to Indian Head. This craft now is quite close to us. So we're puzzled. We have no fear. And I put the window down of the car and waved to it.
[laughs] You waved to the UFO?
Yeah.
[laughs] Oh, Betty!
[laughs] Well about a half a mile beyond that---
Did you get any response? I know that sounds silly but was there any response?
Yeah.
What kind of response?
It came out over the highway and stopped directly in front of us.
So that was the first time---
In midair.
So it was sort of off to the side, but then after you waved out of the car---
It, yep. Came out in front of us.
That's a definite response.
That's a definite response. I remember, Barney had been in the military, World War II.
Okay.
He's curious. What kind of craft is this?
Ah, so he's intellectual---

The military is brought up in discussion several times, both in terms of Barney Hill's service and the military involvement in the abduction case itself. This very real powerful entity looms large over the interview, almost taking on the role of the aliens themselves.
He's never seen anything like this before in the military.
Well Barney was also an avid plane watcher as a hobby for himself wasn't he?
Yep. Well, he'd been in the military, World War II.
Yeah.
And he knew just about everything that flew.
Right.

So, uh, when this craft stopped in midair in front of us, Barney's gonna identify it, if possible. So he takes the binoculars, gets out of the car and walks towards the end of the craft, looking up at it.
So you had stopped at the side of the road and he now starts walking towards this craft?
Yep, and looking up, I'm sitting in the car.
Now how high or low was the craft at this point? It was quite low to the ground at this stage, wasn't it?
Oh, I'd say 50 feet.
50 feet above the ground, out in a field, so at this point---
Right over the highway, right in front of us.
Oh, this wasn't over the field, it was on the highway.
Barney walked towards it.
Okay.
Then it moved out a short ways out into the field.
Okay.
And he started walking out into the field towards it.
Here, Siegel begins to probe Hill for evidence of fear, while Hill resists with her own curiosity.
What did you think when you saw him walking straight for this UFO that's only 50 feet off the ground?
Well I was wondering if he could identify it. [laughs]
[laughs] You weren't worried at all at that point?
Nope.
Okay.
No fears, no nothing.
You both are very intellectually curious.

[laughs] So, and as Barney walks towards it, he's looking up through the binoculars and he sees a light, like a big picture window, lighted. And he sees this group of men standing behind the window looking down at him.
Okay, so he sees beings onboard this craft, several of them looking out the window right at him on the ground, looking back through binoculars.

And as he's watching, one of these men reached behind him and it was like a panel on the wall. And he was moving levers up and down. And at that point the craft started to descend. And as it did, a sort of a narrow wing came out on each side with a red light at the end of the wing.
So wings emerged suddenly?
Yep.
Okay.
And at this point, Barney knew it was something he'd never seen before. And he had the feeling that they were coming down, they were going---they were trying to capture him.
Now let's stop for one second there.

This commercial break was included by the production company that subsequently published The UFO Connection online. These commercials were not included in the original broadcast, and it is difficult to know if and when commercial breaks were taken during the original broadcast. The nature of these commercials reflects the fringe and conspiratorial platforms that continue to promote UFO accounts.
[commercial break]

Here, Siegel reveals her own prior knowledge of the story by prompting Hill to describe the aliens as Betty remembered them after the event; Hill stays in the temporality of the event, recalling only that she thought they looked like normal humans at the moment.
The beings he saw on the craft, did they look like normal human beings?
Well, from what he could see, he assumed they were normal.
He did at that stage?
Yes.
Okay, because we do have sketches we can show the audience that they... as he got a closer look, looked pretty different. Okay, please go on, this is riveting.
So, the craft begins to descend. He becomes frightened, runs back to the car, yelling that they were trying to capture him, and we had to get out of there.
Siegel prompts Hill to foreground the material ephemera of the encounter, the broken binocular strap, anticipating Hill's telling of the story.
Yes. Now he---something happened with the binocular strap, this heavy thick leather binocular strap around his neck.
When---when---we didn't realize it at the time, but when he pulled the binoculars down from his eyes, he did it with such force that it actually broke the strap around his neck.
And he actually had a sore neck for several days afterwards from that, didn't he?
Right.

Okay, alright. So he's running back to the car. Originally, he's out of soundshot from you because of being so far away. Were you trying to call out to him at all while he was in the field? Even though you said you weren't worried about him, did you try to call after him while he was out in the field?
When the craft started to come down, I yelled to him.
Okay.
I'm yelling out, you know, get back in the car. I began to sense danger at that point.
Oh, you too. Okay.
Right.

Alright, so something shifted. At first you were curious and calm, then you both started to get worried. And he came back to the car yelling, they're going to capture us in a very high state of fear and anxiety.
Right.
Okay, what happens now?
This is the first discussion of that sounds of alien abduction. Siegel asks Hill to mimic the sound of the alien beeping noise, which is met with some difficulty.
So we went speeding down the highway and we had just gone a short distance and we heard a beeping, a strange beeping sound.
Can you imitate that at all? I... I...
No, not really. It was sort of tinny, but it was like beep, beep, beep, beep, beep, beep, beep, beep---like that.
Okay.
Here, Siegel prompts Hill with the question of pain, which Hill again resists with a return to curiosity.
And the whole car vibrated.
Oh, was this painful or uncomfortable, the level of vibration?
No, it was just curiosity.
Okay.
You know, what's happening?
Okay.
And at that point I put the window down and put my head out to see if I could see what was happening.
And what did you see?
And at that point the UFO went over the roof of the car.
Now...
And then I lost it. I couldn't see it.
Now, did you actually see the UFO or was it that you couldn't see the star suddenly and assumed it...
Yeah, well, it blocked the sky and I could see the bottom of it.
Could you see any markings or anything on the bottom of the UFO that stands out in your mind?
No, no markings.
Okay, so you heard a beeping coming from the back trunk area of your car. Then you look out the window and see the UFO directly overhead. How low was it, Betty?
Oh, just barely missing the roof.
Oh, how large did it seem to you? That must have been unbelievable.
Oh, it was fairly large because later when we went back we actually took measurements.
And what did you... what was the measurement you came up with?
[coughs] Excuse me. The craft was approximately 60 feet wide.
Between 60 and 65.
I would not want a 60-foot craft flying just inches above my car. That is very alarming, to say the least.
And not only that, missing the trees on both sides. [laughs]
Again, Siegel anticipates the behavior of the abductees, suggesting that "Barney is probably driving a bit wildly and fast," which Hill corrects with her recollection of their immediate calm.

Oh, that's right. That's true. Mountainous roads in New Hampshire are highly treacherous. Oh, for goodness sakes. So Barney is probably driving a bit wildly and fast with this UFO practically landing on your roof. You're both a bit panicked. What happens now?
Then, after---then we calmed right down. And we were watching and we couldn't find the UFO. It was gone. And we said, you know, well, they're gone.
Okay.
Well, then about 30 miles south, Barney turns off the main highway onto a secondary road.
Was this where you planned to go?
No.
No.
Onto a little narrow road.
Now, he did this kind of abruptly, didn't he? Did it kind of startle you that---
Well, you see, I really didn't question it too much because when Barney was traveling, he always studied maps. And he knew every shortcut there was.
So you trusted him?
So I just assumed this was a shortcut.
Okay.
Until we go about half a mile on this road and there were the men that he saw on the craft standing in the middle of the road, blocking our way.
So there's one particular being that he saw on the craft when it was over the field who now he recognized was the same one as standing in the middle of the road. And the craft is where?
On the ground.
On the ground behind the being.
Yup.
In front of your car.
In front of the car.
Blocking your drive.
Yup.
Now what did you feel?
Well, the motor of the car died.
Hill acknowledges her own fear here, her story aligning with the dominant narrative of abduction that Siegel continues to direct her towards.
Oh, you---
And at that moment, I will admit that both Barney and I panicked.
Oh, dear. Oh, dear.
Here we are alone, back mountain road, and here are these men. We don't know who they are.
Okay.
They separated, came up in two groups, took us out of the car.
How many were there?
All together, eleven.
Eleven.
Yup.
So five came up to you, five or six came up to Barney.
Yup.
And did you stay in the car? Did... I mean---
Nope. Actually, when I saw them coming up, I sensed danger. I opened the car door, and I was going to get out and try and run and hide in the woods.
Okay.
But I didn't make it. [laughs] I just got the door open, just started to get out, and they were standing right there in the doorway blocking my way.
Huh. Oh, dear. That must---

And at that point, I went, it was like a loss of memory. It was, for a couple of minutes, I couldn't remember what was happening. And whatever this was, I brought myself out of it, and we're walking in a path in the woods.
Okay.

Being well-aware of the specific evidence that was left behind after the Hills' abduction, Siegel leads in with a question about Barney's scuffed shoes. This foregrounding of evidence represents part of the abductees' search for legitimacy.
Here is the first mention of an altered state of consciousness imposed by the alien captors---mind control is another common theme in the dominant abduction account.
Now, I'm fully conscious, but Barney, they have Barney under some kind of control, and he's having trouble walking. And they're more or less dragging him along.
Now, are his feet dragging behind him?
Yeah.
Sort of like the tops of his shoes are dragging and scraping along the ground as they're---these...
Yeah, because later the tops of his shoes were all scuffed.
Okay. Now, how tall are these beings?
Uh, they were about my height.
And how tall are you, Betty?
Five foot.
So they were shorter than the average male at that time.
Right.
Okay.
Because Barney was taller, much taller than they were.
But they were still managing to hold him up.
Yep.
Okay. And they had a hand---they were kind of holding you from either side as well, just like Barney?
No, I was sort of walking along on my own.
All right. Were you---now, you said you were fully conscious. Did you try to struggle at all or did you---
No, I kept saying, Barney, Barney, Barney, wake up. [laughs] I was trying to wake Barney up.
Yes.

In this exchange, Betty Hill recalls an attempt to resist the aliens' capture. Her boldness and sass in the face of abduction points to an expansion in her limited classification of "abductee" as victimized and violated.
And I wasn't able to. And we get into where the craft was on the ground. Oh, and when I kept calling him Barney, the leader said, his name is Barney. And I said, none of your business.
Oh, you are... you get them. That's right. You're not going to cooperate with them. They're just dragging you off in the middle of the night.
And so now we're at the door of the craft...
In this discussion of the aliens' voices, Betty again recalls the sounds of her abduction experience, without much of an ability to describe the specific sounds she heard.
Now, wait a minute. You said he kept asking you or responding, his name is Barney. Did they talk to you the way... did they have mouths and was there sound coming out?
Yep. They had voices.
They had voices?
Right.
And was clearly speaking English to you.
Yep. Well, it was an accent.
What kind of accent? Did you ever figure it out?
No, I never could figure it out.
Never could. Okay. All right. So they're dragging you and Barney. Barney's unconscious, being dragged behind you.
And now we're at the door of the craft and he said, go on. And I said, no.
You're gonna f---
Again, Betty's resistance to her alien captors also creates more space in the abductee's identity for agency and pushback.
And so they tried to pull me on. And that's when I put up a battle and my dress got torn.
Oh, dear.
And it was the second time I'd worn it. [laughs]
Oh, that's never good. [laughs] What a waste of a good dress, huh? [laughs]

And the one that did the talking said, you know, go on. You're not going to be harmed. All we wanted to do was a simple test. And when the tests are over with, we'll take you back to your car and you'll be on your way home.
So they were trying to encourage you, if you just get on, let us get, you know, get this over with. You'll be back at your car sooner.
Right, you know---
Now, did you trust that? Believe it? What was your reaction?
Well, I didn't have much choice at that moment. So we were taken inside. Barney went in first.
Okay.
And actually it was a corridor. And to go, there was two rooms side by side and the door going into the room was oval shaped like you would find on a ship.
Oh.
And we had to step up to go into the room.
Okay, and---
It was higher than the floor of the corridor.
Now was the corridor straight and boxy?
No, it curved.
It was a curved interior corridor that led to two doorways, one of which you went into and one of which Barney was taken into. And it was an oval doorway with a step up.
Right.
Okay.
Yup. So I went in and there was, well, the man who spoke English, we called him the leader.
Okay.
And he said they wanted to do some tests, simple tests. And then the man, this other man came in and we called him the examiner because he did the testing.
Okay.
And then the nine others stayed out in the corridor.
Oh, okay.
So we called them the crew members.
Okay.
For purposes of identification.

In this moment, Betty Hill seems fed up with Siegel's line of questioning. Her rehearsals have not prepared her for questions that concern the aliens' intentions in separating her from her husband during the examination. The conflict between two competing understandings of the abductees' identity becomes apparent, as well as competing narratives.
Now why do you think you and Barney were in separate rooms?
Why?
Mm-hmm. Yes.
I questioned that and he said that he could only do testing of one at a time.
Mm-hmm.
So they would test me and then he'd go into the next room where Barney was.
Okay.
Which is what happened.
Okay. So if they brought you in at the same time, you'd have to, they'd be taking turns with you. So this was---
Right.
---faster.
Yes.
Okay.
They only had equipment for one person.
Oh, okay.
At a time.

Here, the dissonances in the conversation disrupt both the dominant narrative of abduction and the temporality of the storytelling process. Hill falters trying to answer Siegel’s question, for reasons we cannot speculate about here, but in doing so, she reverts back into her state of mind during her abduction experience. She cannot be that alarmed to be separated from Barney because the entire experience is, in her words, “a new situation.” Her long pause as she struggles to find words seems to remind Siegel of Hill’s identity beyond that of a storyteller; she apologizes to Hill before redirecting the conversation back towards the question, “Were you afraid?”
Was that more alarming to you to be separated from Barney at that stage?
Nope.
No?
Nope. I--- I--- see--- uh---
Sorry---
It's a new situation. You know, I'm playing it by ear. I don't know what's going to happen.
Sure, sure.
For all I know, they might roast me for lunch. [laughs]
[laughs] That's not a---not a very funny thought actually. That's kind of, that---well, how terrified were you at that time?
Well, after I got inside, then I got over being afraid. Well, see, the leader, they were doing all he could to calm us down.
Huh.
I say, we're not going to harm you.
Okay.
We, we just want to find out how you are like us and different from us.
Oh, really?
And then as soon as we find that out, we're going to take you back to the car.
Hmm. Okay, interesting.
Yeah.

By invoking her own sense of awe, even before the abduction concludes, Hill resists her classification as a victim and emphasizes another aspect of the abductees' identity, which is their "chosenness" to be a participant in thie spectacular experience.
Did you think these were beings from another planet or galaxy or another world at that stage?
Oh, yeah.
Yeah. No question in your mind?
No question.
All right, so that made sense.
Astronauts, these were astronauts from another solar system.
All right. Astronauts---
And I was beginning to become impressed.
Astronauts---
I'm getting over my fears and I've got a lot of curiosity now.
Uh-huh.
Yup.
Now, what did, what was in that room that they brought you into? Because you didn't actually see the inside of Barney's room, but what-
No, but they both, later we found out it was the same.
Okay, because of descriptions later.
Actually, the rooms were pie-shaped, like a piece of pie.
Oh, that makes sense if it was a round craft, huh?
Right.
Okay.
And, uh, the lighting was all indirect lighting, ceiling and walls.
Okay.
And it was a bright blue light, very, very bright. And there was like a little table and a stool.
This is another example of Siegel asking a leading question that she clearly knows the answer to in order to prompt Betty Hill to tell her story with the details Siegel wants to hear.
And was the table large enough for a normal adult human to fit on?
No, no. Barney's legs were hanging over the edge.
Oh, my. Okay, so it was a shorter table than you would expect.
Right.
Okay.
Yup. And then there was a cabinet, and then there was some of the equipment they used. It was on the wall. They just slid these doors back and the equipment was sort of built into the wall.
Huh, okay. So they kind of reached up, took it off the wall and then brought it over to where---
No, they just slid the doors back.
Slid the door back? Oh, okay. All right.

The examination is the pinnacle of spectacular and sexualized bodily violation and trauma for the alien abductee, and it is such a hallmark component that it’s practically synonymous with abduction itself. Bridget Brown charts the shift in alien abduction narratives from “the sort of large-scale military conflict posited in The War of the Worlds–type science fictions” to “profoundly intimate, a physical, sexual, and psychological invasion of self” (5). Similarly, literary scholar Patricia Barbeito theorizes that “the aliens’ technological disruption of the natural female body becomes the prevalent way of signaling the traumatic disruption of hegemonic narratives of identity and history” (202).
So, uh, now my examination, first of all, they put me on a stool. And they checked my eyes, ears, nose, throat. They were very interested in my feet. They took samples of my hair.
How? Did they cut it or pull it out or---?
They cut it.
They cut it. So they had, was it a scissor like we're familiar with?
I don't know. I couldn't say what they---I knew they cut it. But I don't know what they used.
And when they looked in your eye---you know when you go to an eye doctor, they have a thing that lights up the inside of your eye or your ear. Did anything look familiar to you?
No, no lights.
No lights. They just were looking and leaning forward and looking. And did any of this hurt at this stage?
No.
Not yet, yeah.

And they also took a scraping of my skin. And then they said they were going to check my nervous system. And they had these, this equipment in the wall. And they pulled these wires out. And they were touching me.
Did that hurt?
No.
No. So they were touching you, not poking you with wires and no shocks.
No, they were putting, you know, touching them. And reading this machine.
Oh, wow.

The exchange about the "pregnancy test" performed on Betty Hill is fascinating, as the two conversational partners switch into very different temporalities and tones. Betty seems to want to speed through this part of the story, while Siegel knows that it is the most salacious moment in Betty's examination and therefore of interest to audiences.
And then he said they were going to do a pregnancy test.
Now how old were you at this stage, by the way, if you don't mind saying?
Forty.
Forty. Okay, that---all right, so they're going to do a pregnancy test.
And this is when he tried to put a needle-like instrument in my navel, which caused pain. So he stopped doing it.
Okay. Now, let's spend a minute on that, though. Actually, before they were about to do the pregnancy test, did you say anything or express anything to them?
No, but when I saw the needle, I said, don't do it. It will hurt.
You warned them.
And he said, no, it shouldn't hurt.
Uh-huh.
And when it did hurt, he was amazed. And he stopped doing it.
Hill and Siegel both present a humane, positive portrait of the aliens here---one marked by understanding and almost mysticism instead of technological violation.
So did they stop or did they also do something to take care of the pain as well, I understand.
Well, he sort of... rubbed... put his hand back and forth in front of my eyes.
Huh.
And that stopped the pain.
So not only did they pull out, even after they pulled the needle out, it still was very painful. He waved his hand in front of your eyes a few times and all the pain went away.
Right.
And what feeling did you have after they had done this intrusive procedure, even though they stopped when you expressed pain?
Well, at that point, my exam was over with.
Uh-huh.
And the examiner went into the next room to give Barney his exam.
Okay.

What is left out of this exchange is just as interesting as what is said. Barney's examination also included the collection of a semen sample, but either this detail was too salacious for television or Hill wants to avoid talking about it. Barney had a much more complex relationship to his own abduction, examination, and the subsequent publicity.

And now this, with Barney, the first part was the same as mine. The eyes, ears, nose, throat, skin, hair, fingernails. And then they rolled him over on his stomach, and they seemed to be mostly interested in his bone structure.
Hmm. Interesting.

Yep. So now the examiner is in with Barney, and I'm beginning to feel like I'm going to be out of there soon. And I'm relaxed. And I said to the leader, I need something to take home with me to prove this happened.
[laughs] You're looking for that ashtray off the UFO, aren't you? [laughs] Or that matchbook cover or something, huh?
And actually, there was a book.
Oh, what did this book look like? I find this fascinating.
So he said I could have the book.
He was going to give you a book off this craft?
Right. So I'm standing there by the cabinet and I'm looking briefly through the book, looking for pictures.
Yeah, that makes---
Because I did see the printing.
Now what did the printing look like? Does it look like anything you have ever seen from any culture or time?
Yep. Oriental.
It looked Oriental. Why? Was it left to right?
Well, because--- well, it was a much simpler script than Japanese.
Okay.
Or Chinese. But it went up and down in columns instead of across.
Okay.
Yep.
Okay.

This anecdote represents Hill's rehearsed storytelling process as it relates to integrating humor and delight, shifting collective understandings of the abductee's relationship to their experience. She does this at the expense of delegitimizing the validity of her story.
And then I'm looking at the book and the examiner comes running back into the room where I am, opens my mouth, and starts tugging at my teeth.
Tugging at them, pulling at your teeth gently, huh?
Yep. And so I said, you know, I'm saying, what's wrong?
Yeah.
And the leader said, we're puzzled. Barney's teeth come---are removable and yours are not. Why?
[laughs] Now why is that?
Actually, World War II. Barney got hit with a hand grenade or something and it knocked all his teeth out.
So Barney had dentures and---
He had dentures.
They figured everybody's teeth came out as a full set and were removable. That's adorable.
They couldn't figure out why his teeth came out and mine did not.
So did they ask you, did you try to explain what that was about?
Yes.
Did they understand?
I'm not really sure if they did.
Now what does it take---how did you describe---how did you try to explain the dentures?
I said that---well, Barney said it was the result of an accident. But as we get older, then---many of us, we lose our teeth, you know.
And what baffled them?
We had to have them extracted.
Right.
And then this led into, well, eat, what do you eat?
Well, he said, what is age, right?
Yep. He was asking me what's age and I'm saying this many years we live and what's diet and I'm trying to explain about foods.
That that affects---
And he's not understanding me.

Yeah, you were trying to explain that, you know, sometimes as people get older, they lose their teeth and then they, and as they age and he says, what's age? And you were trying to explain how different things affect how long a person lives, such as the diet they eat, and then you were trying to explain food and this conversation just kind of fell apart.
I tried---well, I said, I'll tell you about squash.
Because that's your favorite food.
Yeah. And then I said, the first thing I said, it's yellow. And he said, what's yellow? He didn't---he spoke English, but in a limited way.
Okay.
Yeah.
So that conversation---you were working on it, but it was difficult. Now, he also showed you something fascinating, and this is one of the most compelling components of your case.

The star map is one of the biggest pieces of evidence lauded by UFO enthusiasts about the Betty and Barney Hill case. Again, we hear Siegel directing the conversation towards discourses of evidence and legitimacy.
Well, I said to him, I know you're not from this planet. Where are you from? And this is when he showed me the star map.
He showed you a star map.
Right.
And we have drawings of your star map. You drew it later after the event.
Yep. And he said the broken lines were expeditions, places they'd been once or twice.
Okay.
And then the other lines, the solid lines, were places they went frequently or all the time.
Oh, my.
And of course, later I sketched the star map.
Now, was Earth on this map?
Yes.
It was?
We were a spot where they go frequently.
Oh. Now, let's take a minute to say, when you drew the map originally after this event, did anybody recognize that system?
Not at first.
Marjorie Fish was not, in fact, a nuclear scientist by was actually an elementary school teacher and amateur astronomer. Her analysis of the star map has mostly been debunked by scientists.
Now, how long did it take before people recognized that star system?
Well, most of the research was done by a woman by the name of Marjorie Fish. And she worked at Oak Ridge at the nuclear, I don't know, nuclear, something nuclear.
Facility?
Oh, it was a nuclear facility.
Okay.

And she was a scientist. And she was curious about the star map to see if it really existed. And she took boxes and put strings down. And she started out putting us, our solar system in the middle and working out and getting rid of all the stars that we think could not possibly have life.
Okay.
And when she got through, there was my star map almost completed.
You mean she did that independently of looking at your map?
Yep.
Oh, for heaven's sake. So in her mind---
She had to get acquainted with every star in the neighborhood.
That is fascinating. And it was the same, almost the same map as yours. What year was that?
Well, she didn't complete the research until 1970.
Okay. It was many years.
Because I had two stars on the map and our astronomers had not found them yet.
When did they find those other stars?
So I had two stars on the map that we had not found yet.
Oh my, for nine years.
And in 1970, we found them.
Oh, fantastic evidence. I absolutely love that.
And not only that, that pattern of stars can be seen only south of Mexico City. So it wasn't anything I looked up and saw in the sky.

In this moment, Betty Hill hangs up the phone to take a break. Here, we can hear the fruits of her rehearsed storytelling practice; through repeated rehearsal, she understands her own limitations in speaking for prolonged periods.
Fascinating. Oh, Betty, this is just one of the most exciting aspects of this case. Now, do you need to take a quick break?
Yes, I should.

You should. Okay, so we're going to stay on the air, absolutely. And you come back as soon as you're done, and we'll continue from where left off towards the end of your exam, and you just got through looking at the star map. And we'll pick up from there when you get back. Okay?
Okay, I'll be right back. Thank you.

Siegel fills the dead air with context and history surrounding the case, again foregrounding the "indisputability" of her claims. She also recognizes Barney Hill's death for the first time, and notably, without Betty on the line.

Alright. [line hangs up] Alright. Now, so we have been talking---this is of course The UFO Connection, and we have just been talking with Betty Hill. All right, I think I'm supposed to switch cameras. Now, just to give you some background information. Where a lot of this information---a lot of this has been written down. Betty and Barney Hill---Barney unfortunately passed away in 1969 of a very severe stroke and died suddenly. But, um, their story has been written up. One of the most famous versions of their story is The Interrupted Journey by John Fuller. I have a very old, whoops, I see the---let me just pick it up here. And in this book we have some very amazing pictures of the star map, of the people involved. We're going to be getting to further versions later. And this actually has transcripts, word-by-word---we haven't gotten to it yet, but afterwards they underwent a great deal of hypnosis with a clinical medical doctor and psychiatrist to retrieve a lot of their memories. They had a lot to begin with, but more came back later [swallows] excuse me, through the hypnosis.

But also in a remarkable series of articles in the MUFON UFO journal from September 2001. And it's just amazing. For those of you who don't have these articles or books available, I'm certain you could find it on the web. Like I said, they are by far the most important and significant abduction case that has ever occurred. And what we're going to be getting to, um a little bit---in a few minutes when Betty returns back on the air, we're going to talk about the enormous list of physical evidence that remained. And how---the thing that I also want you to know is the level of credibility that for over 40 years, nobody---hardcore scientists or anybody---have been able to punch holes into their story. It has truly been examined in detail and it is magnificent.

So I hope you do take the time to look into this case a little bit more if you haven't, I'm sure a lot of our viewers, being so savvy, have, but if you haven't, it's just to get the level of detail---I've immersed myself recently in the case, and it's absolutely fascinating. So... basically what we're doing now is waiting for Betty Hill.
I'm back.

She's back! Yes! Hi Betty, thank you. Good, I'm sitting on the edge of my seat. I want to hear more. Okay, can we pick up right where we left off? You're on the craft, you've just been shown the star map, you're done with your physical exam, and you're holding this book. Does it have pages like we have in normal books with a thick cover and normal paper-feeling pages?
It was very similar to an encyclopedia. Only the pages were very, very smooth and stiff.
Okay, and what color were the pages and the ink or the writing on it?
White with black print.
Same as our books, okay. Have you ever written down any of the letters or words or symbols that you saw in that book?
Oh, I did years ago.
Oh!
I'm very involved in archaeology and anytime I see any ancient writings I check it out. No success.
No success. Have you shown it to other linguists?
Oh yeah, several people have worked on it.
And has anybody ever said it looks somewhat like this or is anybody---
Nope.
Totally unfamiliar.
Still looking.
Very interesting.
Yep.
Okay, so now you're holding this book.

Here, we hear Betty Hill avoiding a question about Barney's state following the examination. Again, the motives for leaving out Barney Hill's much more traumatic and unsettling examination procedure are unclear.
Yep, and I'm ready to---after I saw the star map and all, they brought the---they're bringing Barney out of the room.
And how does he look now?
The mention of the alien language and attempt to recreate it brings the sounds of abduction back into the conversation.
And he's leaving the craft so I pick up the book and I start to go out behind him, when the crew members start yelling.
Now do they---
To my having the book.
Now do they make actual sounds?
Oh yeah, they were mad. You could tell from the tone of their voice they were furious.
Were they using words or...?
Well I couldn't understand what they were saying. They had a language of their own.
I know in the book it was described as like [humming] like humming almost.
Almost like a humming sound.
Almost like a humming, okay. So they're all---
So the leader took the book back.
Oh, what did he say or what did you say?
Oh I became angry at first.
Yeah.
And then he said he would walk part of the way back to the car with me.
He said, I have to take the book back because the crew members don't want you to remember or have---don't---
He said I have no objections to you having the book but they do.
So it's obviously a community agreement concept among them even though he's the leader.

Again, Betty Hill invokes an awe-inspired affect when describing the end of her abduction. This foregrounds the special, close relationship that appears to have been built between the two parties, not the one-sided capture of a human specimen.

So they're leading Barney and then I leave the craft and the leader starts walking with me. And he gets almost up to the car and he stops and he's going to leave. And I said to him, this has been the greatest experience of my life. I have been honored to meet you. I have many friends who would like to meet you. Will you please come back? And he said I don't know. It's not my decision to make.
So even---
So I said, well if you decide to come back, how will I know this? And he said, you will know somehow.
Oh.
And with that---oh, and then he said stay by the car. And you'll be far enough away from the craft so you won't be in any danger when we leave.
Oh interesting.

[coughs] So I went to the car and Barney's sitting in the car and I said come on, get out, watch 'em leave. And I picked up the dog, my dog Delsey, a Dachshund. And we're standing there, we're watching the craft leave. It becomes surrounded with this red fiery substance. It looks almost like fire but it's not.
Wow.

It lifts out of it and it dips up. And I'm saying to the dog, Delsey, look at this. You may be the only dog in the world to see this. And she's scared to death, she's got her head tucked under my arm.
Awww.
She won't look.
Awww.
So we get in the car and we go home.
Awww. So the whole time you and Barney were on the craft, Delsey, your dachshund, was cowering and staying put in the car without you, scared.
Right.
Okay.
Yep.

So you watched---so even though you have been, you know, against your will, both you and Barney dragged out of your car, given a physical exam, underwent some degree of physical pain, you still felt honored to have met them and were hoping to have a future encounter.
Right.
When it was all over---
I didn't want to come back.
Okay. So you watched the craft fly away, you get back in the car, now what happens? There's even more.
We drive home. We drive home and we get home and---
Another instance of Siegel anticipating the narrative before Hill arrives there in her own telling.
Uneventfully you get home? Something happened, wasn't there something?
No.
Wasn't there some missing time or?
Oh well, when we got home, Barney said, you know, gosh, the trip took longer than what it should.
About two hours longer, at least.
Right.
About two hours longer.
And then we found a highly polished spot on the trunk of the car, apparently where the beeping sounds had originated.
So when you went to look at the trunk of your car, on the surface, there were highly polished, perfectly round surfaces.
Yup.
Like marks or something.
Shiny spots.
Now there was more beeping on the way home. See there's a segment that after you, the UFO flew off---
Oh! When we got back, yeah, we left the craft, but we got back on the main highway.
Okay.
They beeped us again.
Okay.
And this is when I said, I don't know where they're going, but I wish them good luck.
Now you had kind of a shift in consciousness as well when that beeping occurred, didn't you?
Yup.
What would you say your state of consciousness was right after the craft flew away, you were driving and, you know, and right after you heard the beep, about 30 minutes later?
Well, like, particularly with Barney, he was fully conscious.
Okay.
But even before that, he was still sort of, oh, how would I put it? He was sort of dazed.
Dazed.
Yup. But when we heard the second beeping sound, he was wide awake.
Okay. It was like something shifted in this fog or daze or haze.
Yup.
It was lifted off you instantly from that sound. And then after you got home, there actually were physical marks left on your car. How long did those marks remain on your car?
Oh, the marks stayed there for months.
Even though you polished and waxed the car, did they always still stand out?
Yup. They stayed there for months.
They stayed there for months. Now, did you do any testing on those spots after you got home?
Well, we talked with a physicist who said, put a compass around them, see what happens.
So you did that the next day after you got home.
Right. And the compass was very erratic.
Okay. Meaning it was---
It reacted differently over those spots than any other place.
On the car.
Right.
And they were spinning wildly when you held it near the polished spots, but not when you moved it a few inches to the side.
Yup.
Okay.
And then the tops of Barney's shoes were scuffed.
Now, Barney is very, was---from what I read, was very meticulous about his appearance and couldn't figure out how the tops of his shoes were scuffed.
His new shoes.
New shoes.
Right. [laughs]

In this exchange, Hill reasserts her agency over the narrative she's telling by correcting Siegel, who incorrectly assumes that Betty can't remember what time their watches stopped working. Hill's correction allows her to regain control over the story.
You both lost your wardrobe on this trip. Okay, so his shoes were scuffed. What else? What about your watches? Wasn't there---
And both of our watches had stopped functioning.
Now, did they both stop at the exact same time?
We don't know.
Oh, you can't remember.
Because, you know, his watch stopped. Your watch stops and you wind it up and you sort of try to get it going again.
Oh, of course, these are the days---
And that's what we did, so we never did really know what time.
Oh, that's too bad. Okay, now what about your dress?
Okay, now, my dress. I took it off and I put it in the back of the closet. And about three weeks later, I went to get my dress and it was covered with a pink powdery substance.
Did it have a smell to it or anything, like---
Not that I noticed.
And what was the texture like? Baby powder, like---
Yeah, it was like a... I would say, sort of like a talcum powder.
Okay.
But it was pink.
Pink?
And I put the dress outdoors and the powder blew away.
Oh, goodness.
But it left pink stains all over my dress.
Now, can you account for what that was? Did they do anything to you during the encounter that you remember them touching you in a certain spot?

Nope. And ever since then, different labs have tried to analyze---in fact, right now, there's an attempt being made to try to analyze what would cause pink stains. We know what would cause blue---the dress was blue.
Okay.
So we knew what would cause blue stains or gray stains, but no idea what causes pink.

Siegel uses a common trope of argument for UFO enthusiasts, which attempts to explain away the lack of sufficient evidence by insinuating that alien technology is far too advanced for humans to understand or interpret. This allows a great deal of plausible deniability in the gathering of evidence.

Fascinating. Well, I would love to hear when you get the results back from that test, if they are able to determine it. Maybe they don't have sophisticated enough equipment. Also, your dress from struggling, what happened to your---
Yeah, my dress was torn.
Your dress was torn.
Yeah.
So that dress---
It was one of these dresses that had the built-in lining.
Yes.
And the lining is all torn.
Oh, dear. Do you still have that---
All the seams were torn out.
Oh, my. Do you still have that dress, Betty?
Oh, yes.
Oh, my goodness.
Yep.
[laughs] That is a famous dress to hang on to, I must say. Oh, my goodness.
Then, let's see---
You had so much. When you got home, how did you feel when you first got home? Like, my goodness, what a harrowing experience. You kind of walk in your house late at night, later than you expected.
We got home about five o'clock in the morning.
Oh, my.

This is the first mention of any physical symptoms or illnesses described by Hill in the aftermath of her experience. This visceral detail works to reify the dominant abduction narrative characterized by a feeling of violation and discomfort.
And actually, we both felt---the only way we could describe it is contaminated.
Huh.
So we both took long showers, shampooed our hair and all.
Wow.
But we did not bathe the dog. And I would say two weeks afterwards, she had all kinds of skin rashes.
Oh, my. I didn't know that.
We had her back and forth to the vet for two years.
Oh, dear. Do you think there was some kind---[feedback] whoops, we're having a little feedback here. Do you think that was some kind of radiation exposure or from that pink dust off your dress?
I don't know, but whatever it was, she was very uncomfortable. I mean, she had big boils.
Oh, dear. Is that a symptom of radiation exposure?
I have no idea.
Okay, all right.
And the vet didn't know what was doing it. He just said she came in contact with something but did not agree with her.
Yeah. Now, did you or Barney---[feedback] oh, could we get rid of the feedback in here? Did you or Barney have any illness as a result of your encounter?
No, not then.
No.
But then...

Okay, good. Now, what about how were your emotions after the fact? As much as you felt good about that encounter, what was your overall emotional state following this event like over the next few weeks and months?
Yeah, well, Barney wanted to forget all about it. He didn't want to talk about it because he couldn't explain it.
Kind of like a resistance thing. He just doesn't know what to make of it. Just make it go away.
Not me. I was fascinated.
Okay.
In fact, I reported it to the police.
Now, what did the police say? Did they make fun of you?
They told me to call Pease Air Force Base and report it.
Now, what did they say?
So I called Pease Air Force Base.
Now, they had a special responsibility in 1961, actually. They were, in fact, collecting UFO reports at the time, weren't they?
Yep. And, well, they called us back several times. And then one time they said that our phone call was going to another base, not Pease.
Okay.

This exchange involves Hill reminiscing about her notoriety, her "specialness" after the abduction events went public. Siegel, not being able to fit this into her definition of abductees' experiences, is at a loss for how to respond.
And then later, that was the beginning.
Now, was there any...
From then on, Barney and I, every Friday night we're out at the officer's club. [laughs]
So you got some---
We knew all the pilots.
Uh-huh.
Yep.

Now, unfortunately, we're going to run out of time soon, which I can't believe it went that fast. This is just horrible. But tell me, did they find any---did the Air Force or the air base have any evidence to corroborate your story?

Well, that was another thing we learned, was that they had picked the craft up on radar, had sent up two military planes to check it out, and from their report, we know that the craft left at 2:14 AM.

Oh. So they---the military base, the Air Force base, picked your craft up on radar, and there's radar evidence that they were, in fact, in the vicinity that you said they were at the time you said they were?
Yep.
Oh, boy. And they weren't making fun of you at all. In fact, they actually took your case and treated it very seriously, correct?
We were---well, I had continuing contacts from that time up until the time the base closed, which was, I think, 1986. Yep.
Wow.
And not only that, I used to go at the invitation of the Air Force, used to go around to Air Force bases and lecture on UFOs.
You're kidding. You were invited by military Air Force bases to lecture on UFOs?
Oh, yeah.
Oh, Betty, that's incredible! That is incredible! Good for you!
But not only that, after a while, somebody would call to report a UFO, and they'd tell them to call me.
Now, how do you feel about getting these calls from strangers who have had experiences?
Oh, I still get them.
You feel what?
I'm still receiving UFO reports.

You're so friendly. You'll talk to anybody, won't you? [laughs] That is delightful. In fact, you told me that you wrote a chapter for a recent book called The Culture of New Hampshire, just a nice book about the culture of New Hampshire where you live, and you were...
Yep.
Go ahead. You were asked to write a chapter?
Uh-huh. I wrote it on the history of UFOs in New Hampshire.
So New Hampshire, you also told me, is very open-minded and accepting about UFOs, aren't they?
Right. In fact, the earliest reports that I have go back to 1932 because it had no name for them. They just called them flying things.
Uh-huh.
And they were seen about every two years up until World War II. And, because World War II, we had the volunteers sitting out nights, all night, watching the sky for enemy planes.
Oh!

And then they would see these lights in the sky, would call the report in to a central location. And that person---at that time we didn't have Pease Air Force Base here---they would call the reports in to the Air Force Base in Plattsburg, New York. And the planes there would come out and check out these strange lights. And there were thousands of them.
Wow. In fact, the night of your event, the Air Force Base actually sent two military craft to check out what they were picking up on radar too.
Right.

Yeah. Now, you also told me that New Hampshire, in your local paper, on the front page there was a whole article, there were so many UFO reports coming in that they said, tell us what the article said, real quickly because we're almost out of time.
It said, if you see a UFO, do not call 911. It's not an emergency.

Because too many calls were coming in. I just love it. Now, and one more important thing I want the viewers to hear. You told me since that event, up until they built a development, a housing development, you had huge open space that you could see from your home, you know, a big open area. What has been happening every night for 15 years?
UFOs coming in.
You have...
See, about six weeks after the experience itself, Barney and I came home one night and found a pile of dried leaves on the kitchen table.
Uh-huh.
And in the pile of dried leaves was my blue earrings that I was wearing that night.
That disappeared the night of your abduction and six weeks later they mysteriously appeared on your...
Kitchen table.
Kitchen table. Is that when the sightings in your area began?
And it was soon after that.
And how many, do you think it was the same beings and craft that you encountered the night of your abduction?
They had to bring back the earrings. And yes.
[laughs] Okay.

Well, then when Barney and I would go out at night, we'd drive along and UFOs would pace our car. And sometimes they'd put on a little show for us. And then in this one town, about... I would say at least 50% of the people sat out every night, along with lots of other people, for about 15 years and observed UFOs.
And how many different, just give me a number because we're out of time. How many different types of crafts, styles of crafts have you observed?
We filmed about 200 different kinds.
200 different styles of crafts in this one area of New Hampshire outside your home of Portsmouth over a 15-year period with thousands of witnesses.
Right.
Fantastic.
And scientists and Air Force and police and... We did all kinds of experiments, scientific testing---
Betty---
TV cameras.

Betty, can we get you back on the show sometime? I feel like we barely scratched the surface. You are the most fascinating, interesting guest and delightful to talk to, but I'm so heartbroken. We have run out of time.
Well, I can think about about 10 more subjects.
Oh, can we get you back? Do you agree to come back on sometime?
Okay, Give me a call.
Oh, we would love that. Thank you so much, everybody---
